issue.title: ee key too small has occured in nginx with debian:bookworm-slim
issue.body:
I'm trying to create a Dockerfile for nginx with debian:bookworm-slim based on oqs-demos/nginx image.
However, i got an `ee key too small` error for server cert when I checked nginx config using `nginx -c /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t`.
I believe my Dockerfile is wrong because it should work with other images than alpine.
Here are the details.
### To Reproduce 
1. [Download Dockerfile](https://github.com/feuxfollets1013/oqs-demos/blob/e47faaacbb52a4dc822ec52b515a5b7a7c7595d7/nginx/Dockerfile.debian)
2. `docker build --file ./Dockerfile.debian -t oqs-nginx-debian:latest .`
3. `docker run --rm -it oqs-nginx-debian /bin/bash`
4. `./sbin/nginx -c nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t`
5. `ee key too small` error has occured.

comment.body:
>> docker build command completes and server certificate verfication using openssl succeeds.
> That's good. And you did use a PQ algorithm as a cert for testing? If not,

I used dilithium3.

> A typical error cause is an incorrectly set OPENSSL_MODULES variable: Are you sure this is correctly set? And that oqsprovider is specified for use?

This was the cause. I set OPENSSL_MODULES variable and ran `nginx -t` command and it succeeded.
```
oqs@43d75122bbe6:/opt/nginx/sbin$ ./nginx -c /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t
2023/12/18 22:38:38 [emerg] 15#0: SSL_CTX_use_certificate("/opt/nginx/pki/server.crt") failed (SSL: error:03000072:digital envelope routines::decode error error:0A00018F:SSL routines::ee key too small)
nginx: [emerg] SSL_CTX_use_certificate("/opt/nginx/pki/server.crt") failed (SSL: error:03000072:digital envelope routines::decode error error:0A00018F:SSL routines::ee key too small)
nginx: configuration file /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf test failed

oqs@43d75122bbe6:/opt/nginx/sbin$ export OPENSSL_MODULES=/opt/openssl/lib64/ossl-modules/

oqs@43d75122bbe6:/opt/nginx/sbin$ ./nginx -c /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t
nginx: the configuration file /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf syntax is ok
nginx: configuration file /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf test is successful
```

Thank you for helping me solve the problem.

issue.title: Falcon constant time tests failing
issue.body: The [Falcon CT CI tests are failing since quite a few weeks](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/workflows/weekly.yml) coincidentally with the last commit ([adding uninstall support](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1604) -- but I somehow cannot imagine how this should impact CT for Falcon). Other thoughts what could be at play welcome.

comment.body: I'm very familiar with Falcon code base due to my work with Falcon aarch64. Can you give me a brief instruction how to enable constant time test locally so I can (hopefully) help out?

issue.title: ee key too small has occured in nginx with debian:bookworm-slim
issue.body:
I'm trying to create a Dockerfile for nginx with debian:bookworm-slim based on oqs-demos/nginx image.
However, i got an `ee key too small` error for server cert when I checked nginx config using `nginx -c /opt/nginx/nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t`.
I believe my Dockerfile is wrong because it should work with other images than alpine.
Here are the details.
### To Reproduce 
1. [Download Dockerfile](https://github.com/feuxfollets1013/oqs-demos/blob/e47faaacbb52a4dc822ec52b515a5b7a7c7595d7/nginx/Dockerfile.debian)
2. `docker build --file ./Dockerfile.debian -t oqs-nginx-debian:latest .`
3. `docker run --rm -it oqs-nginx-debian /bin/bash`
4. `./sbin/nginx -c nginx-conf/nginx.conf -t`
5. `ee key too small` error has occured.

comment.body: Thanks for confirming that setting `OPENSSL_MODULES` solved the issue.

issue.title: Falcon constant time tests failing
issue.body: The [Falcon CT CI tests are failing since quite a few weeks](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/workflows/weekly.yml) coincidentally with the last commit ([adding uninstall support](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1604) -- but I somehow cannot imagine how this should impact CT for Falcon). Other thoughts what could be at play welcome.

comment.body:
> I'm very familiar with Falcon code base due to my work with Falcon aarch64. Can you give me a brief instruction how to enable constant time test locally so I can (hopefully) help out?

Thank you very much for this offer, @cothan ! All CT logic is visible in [this CI test](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/.github/workflows/weekly.yml): In essence, you need a Linux image with `valgrind` installed (we have prepared "openquantumsafe/ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64:latest" for this), build `liboqs` with the required instrumentation for the platform of choice (e.g., `cmake` args -DOQS_DIST_BUILD=OFF -DOQS_OPT_TARGET=generic -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DOQS_ENABLE_TEST_CONSTANT_TIME=ON) and execute the [test script](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/test_constant_time.py). At its beginning a full explanation is contained in comments.

issue.title: how to integrate provider with openssl no-shared static build
issue.body:
Currently the fullbuild.sh https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/scripts/fullbuild.sh#L54 is configuring openssl without no-shared.

I tried to build openssl static with no-shared, build provider.so, and try to do it's not listing any oqs provider. Ami I missing anything here?

OPENSSL_MODULES=. ./openssl-static list -provider oqsprovider -verbose

comment.body: I'm not sure I fully understand the question: Do you want to build a static binary for openssl that _contains_ `oqsprovider` without changing the Makefile structures of `openssl`? If so, I wouldn't know how that should be possible: For example, `openssl` does not know where the code for `oqsprovider` needs to be linked into (and I don't know that either). Maybe this is a question for [openssl](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/discussions/new?category=q-a)? Maybe also helpful could be https://github.com/openssl/openssl/discussions/21410

issue.title: Fix BIKE constant-time errors
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

I have reviewed the [BIKE constant-time test failures](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/runs/7154812712/job/19482761520) and identified the offending lines of code. They are summarized below.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/sampling_portable.c#L44

This appears to be triggered by the array access `pos_qw[j]`. After reviewing the function's code, I believe this to be a false positive and have documented it as a "pass". There's an existing pass for the AVX2 version of this function.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/decode_portable.c#L40

The issue here seems to be the "<" operator. I changed this to `!(bits >> 6)` and it now passes (on my machine).

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L44

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L45

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L50

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L51

These array accesses depend on the value of `a0`, which is one of the function arguments. Hence, I believe this to be (possible) secret-dependent behaviour. I added short loops to perform the array access in a secret-independent fashion, as is done [in HQC](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/hqc/pqclean_hqc-128_clean/gf2x.c#L49).

After these changes, the constant-time tests pass for all variants of BIKE on my machine.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1624.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
Following up on discussion in today's OQS meeting: I am running into a snag when attempting to resolve the constant-time error raised for this line of code: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/decode_portable.c#L40

My initial thought was that the error was raised because of the use of "<" operator for comparison. My "quick fix" of using a bitshift to check the `bits < 64` condition satisfied the Valgrind-powered constant-time tests but caused the Clang static analyzer to fail (see [here](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/3078/workflows/0c99ebaf-628d-4c11-9fd3-da4de27f53fc/jobs/24608?invite=true#step-103-1624_132)). Presumably, the static analyzer doesn't recognize that `!(bits >> 6)` and `bits < 64` are equivalent and is reporting an error because the assert statement may fail. I'm not sure how to resolve this in a way that will satisfy both the static analyzer and the constant-time tests. I'm also not certain that the "<" operator was causing the test failure in the first place.

If somebody more familiar with the inner workings of BIKE could take a look and offer input on
1. whether or not this constitutes secret-dependent behaviour
2. if yes, how to resolve it in a way that keeps the static analyzer happy.

Feedback on the other constant-time errors (and my proposed fixes) would also be very welcome!

issue.title: Fix BIKE constant-time errors
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

I have reviewed the [BIKE constant-time test failures](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/runs/7154812712/job/19482761520) and identified the offending lines of code. They are summarized below.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/sampling_portable.c#L44

This appears to be triggered by the array access `pos_qw[j]`. After reviewing the function's code, I believe this to be a false positive and have documented it as a "pass". There's an existing pass for the AVX2 version of this function.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/decode_portable.c#L40

The issue here seems to be the "<" operator. I changed this to `!(bits >> 6)` and it now passes (on my machine).

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L44

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L45

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L50

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L51

These array accesses depend on the value of `a0`, which is one of the function arguments. Hence, I believe this to be (possible) secret-dependent behaviour. I added short loops to perform the array access in a secret-independent fashion, as is done [in HQC](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/hqc/pqclean_hqc-128_clean/gf2x.c#L49).

After these changes, the constant-time tests pass for all variants of BIKE on my machine.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1624.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Tagging @crockeea who kindly offered to pass this along to somebody who knows about BIKE.

issue.title: Implementation of Composite Sig
issue.body:
This is an implementation of the version 10 [Composite Signatures For Use In Internet PKI](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/).
Current status of this work:
- I'm working on fixing the issues pointed by the Git Actions workflow tests.
- There will be alterations to update this for version 11 when it is released.
- To be precise with the IETF draft, we need to wait for ML-DSA-ipd to be implemented.

comment.body:
Hello Michael, that is unfortunate but the branch suggestion sounds good.
A bit update, I already made the changes for v11, and I'm working on the git actions issues.

issue.title: Fix BIKE constant-time errors

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/decode_portable.c#L40

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L44

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L45

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L50

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/gf2x_mul_base_portable.c#L51

These array accesses depend on the value of `a0`, which is one of the function arguments. Hence, I believe this to be (possible) secret-dependent behaviour. I added short loops to perform the array access in a secret-independent fashion, as is done [in HQC](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8449e546491e77b52ca5b2f1451086ef564e16aa/src/kem/hqc/pqclean_hqc-128_clean/gf2x.c#L49).

After these changes, the constant-time tests pass for all variants of BIKE on my machine.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1624.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> 1. whether or not this constitutes secret-dependent behaviour

It would constitute secret-dependent behaviour if the condition could ever fail. however, we are calling the function here: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/src/kem/bike/additional_r4/decode_portable.c#L62 where we explicitly reduce the input mod 64.

> 2. if yes, how to resolve it in a way that keeps the static analyzer happy.

we should just remove the assert, it's pointless because we reduce the argument mod 64 before calling the function.
